p: Trimethyltin (TMT), a neurotoxic organotin, induces severe neurodegeneration and neuronal death in the central nervous system, particularly in the hippocampus [ 1]. Clinical features of TMT intoxication include headache, cognitive impairment, insomnia, and tonic-clonic seizures [ 2, 3]. These neurological and behavioral signs and symptoms are clinically similar to those of temporal lobe epilepsy, which is common in adults [ 4, 5]. Thus, TMT-intoxicated animal models may be successfully used as a model for limbic system neurodegeneration or temporal lobe epilepsy [ 6]. Various mechanisms have been investigated to understand the etiopathology of TMT-induced neurodegeneration; the accumulation of excessive reactive oxygen species (ROS) has been proposed as one of the main underlying mechanisms [ 7, 8].
